David,

Recently I have been at Java One.  There is an interesting new development,
which
will enable what you are talking about for tool vendors.

Essentially it is an attribute/meta-data based programming, where you will
be able
to decorate any class, variable, method with meta data which will be
available for examination
via Reflection API; this will enable for tool-vendors to write code that
removes test or
any other methos that you would like.  I think this is something considered
for JDK1.5.

Evil Gates, has this sort of functionality built into all the .NET
languages.

Later, Mikhail.

-----Original Message-----
From: David Jared [mailto:dajared@...]

Subject: RE: [junit] Where to place test classes?



Has any consideration been given to extending the Java
language specification to help resolve this issue? For
example, methods can be designated "static" or
"final". What about a "test" designation?  This would
allow tests to be easily included inside classes, but
the tests could be removed in a "release" compile.  

Java was developed before unit testing was a part of
standard software development work pactices.  The idea
of extending the language for testability may present
some unique possibilies.

Thanks,
David Jared
